Throughout Coach Kennedy’s long journey to defend that right, he has been a true example of grace, kindness & respect. 6/6 #pray50

After a years-long legal battle, I am hopeful there will be justice for Coach Kennedy and SCOTUS will uphold this fundamental right of all Americans, including public school teachers & coaches, to live out their faith. 5/6

In America, we can have a faith and we can live that faith. The only thing Coach Kennedy is guilty of is practicing that faith. I was proud to lead 23 of my Senate colleagues and 32 House Members in filing a brief with the Supreme Court in support of Coach Kennedy. 4/6

The school demanded he stop praying after games, and later terminated him because of this freedom of expression and for simply living the principles of his sincere faith. I sent a letter to the school in 2015 in support of Coach Kennedy’s right to pray.  3/6

Coach Kennedy was the head coach for the Bremerton High School junior varsity football team & asst. coach for varsity. After each game he waited until the players cleared the field then took a knee to pray silently. 2/6
This morning, Coach Kennedy will finally have the chance to defend his constitutional right to freely practice his faith at the Supreme Court. 1/6

The military dogs who protected us during my tours in Iraq were essential to keeping us safe, so it was really powerful to see this hallowed ground where canine heroes from all the way back to WWII are laid to rest. 4/5

These legislative victories are a testament to all of the survivors who have stepped forward to share their stories. We have a long way to go, but one thing is clear: This is the Congress that stands up for survivors.

And last year, President Biden signed into law the VOCA Fix to Sustain the Crime Victims Fund Act—a law that, like VAWA, will help survivors of domestic violence and victims of violent crimes access the professional services they desperately need.

The Senate also passed the Eliminating Limits to Justice for Child Sex Abuse Victims Act—a @SenatorDurbin & @MarshaBlackburn bill introduced following the Committee’s Nassar hearing to ensure that survivors of child sex abuse can seek justice no matter when their abuse occurred.

The same month as VAWA's reauthorization, President Biden signed into law the bipartisan Ending Forced Arbitration of Sexual Assault and Sexual Harassment Act, sponsored in the Senate by Chair @SenatorDurbin and Senators @gillibrandny and @LindseyGrahamSC.

The March passage of the #VAWA Reauthorization Act—led by @SenatorDurbin, @SenJoniErnst, @SenFeinstein, and @lisamurkowski—was a major milestone in a growing list of legislative victories for survivors of sexual assault and intimate partner violence during this Congress.

This Committee's oversight of the Larry Nassar case didn't end there. In November and February, @SenatorDurbin, @SenFeinstein, & @ChuckGrassley sent additional oversight letters to continue to hold the FBI’s feet to the fire.
https://www.judiciary.senate.gov/press/dem/releases/feinstein-durbin-grassley-call-for-additional-information-on-fbis-response-to-nassar-case
